meanings.def: to continue to have something and not give it back or throw it away
examples: He kept all her letters.
She handed the waiter a hundred dollar bill and told him to keep the change.
Always keep a backup of the file.

meanings.def: to put or store something in a particular place
examples: Keep your passport in a safe place.
Where do you keep the sugar?
The documents are all kept under lock and key.

meanings.def: to save something for somebody
examples: keep something for somebody Please keep a seat for me.
The man in the shop said he'd keep it for me until Friday.
keep somebody something Please keep me a seat.

meanings.def: to stay in a particular condition or position; to make somebody/something do this
examples: keep + adj. We huddled together to keep warm.
I could not keep silent any longer.
keep + adv./prep. The notice said ‘Keep off (= Do not walk on) the grass’.
Keep left along the wall.
keep somebody/something + adj. The doctors worked miracles to keep him alive.
Winning the contract means they can now keep the factory open.
She kept the children amused for hours.
Keep your PIN safe.
keep somebody/something + adv./prep. He kept his coat on.
Don't keep us in suspense—what happened next?
keep something She had trouble keeping her balance.
keep somebody/something doing something I'm very sorry to keep you waiting.
I'm amazed that she keeps so cheerful.
Keep close to me.
She needed to keep busy.
Sit down and keep calm!
Try to keep active in the cold weather.
We managed to keep dry by standing in a doorway.

meanings.def: to continue doing something; to do something repeatedly
examples: keep doing something Keep smiling!
Why does everyone keep saying that?
Things just keep getting worse.
keep on doing something Don't keep on interrupting me!

meanings.def: to know something and not tell it to anyone
examples: Can you keep a secret?
She kept her past secret from us all.

meanings.def: to do what you have promised to do; to go where you have agreed to go
examples: She kept her promise to visit them.
Mary kept her word and Henry was never informed.
He failed to keep his appointment at the clinic.

meanings.def: to write down something as a record
examples: She kept a diary for over twenty years.
We keep a record of all complaints that we receive.
Keep a note of where each item can be found.
I kept a weekly account of my workload and activities.
Separate accounts must be kept for each different business activity.
Village clerks were unable to keep a proper record of deaths because they were so frequent.

meanings.def: to own and care for animals
examples: to keep bees/goats/hens
My grandmother kept chickens in her back yard.
Residents are not allowed to keep pets.

meanings.def: to own and manage a shop or restaurant
examples: Her father kept a grocer's shop.

meanings.def: to provide what is necessary for somebody to live; to support somebody by paying for food, etc.
examples: He scarcely earns enough to keep himself and his family.
At the time many working men did not earn enough to keep a wife and children.
He kept himself by giving private lessons.

meanings.def: to delay somebody
examples: You're an hour late—what kept you?
I won't keep you long. I've just got a couple of quick questions.

meanings.def: used to ask or talk about somebody’s health
examples: How is your mother keeping?
We're all keeping well.

meanings.def: to remain in good condition
examples: Finish off the pie—it won't keep.
Milk and cream should keep quite well in a fridge.
(informal, figurative) ‘I'd love to hear about it, but I'm late already.’ ‘That's OK—it'll keep (= I can tell you about it later).’

meanings.def: to protect somebody from something
examples: keep somebody May the Lord bless you and keep you (= used in prayers in the Christian Church).
keep somebody from something His only thought was to keep the boy from harm.

meanings.def: to guard or protect the goal or wicket
to make an effort to live normally when you are in a difficult situation or when you have experienced great pain and difficulty
examples: You just have to keep yourself busy and keep going.

meanings.def: used to encourage somebody to continue doing something
examples: Keep going, Sarah, you're nearly there.

meanings.def: to be enough for somebody until they get what they are waiting for
examples: Have an apple to keep you going till dinner time.

idioms.def: to make an effort to live normally when you are in a difficult situation or when you have experienced great pain and difficulty
examples: You just have to keep yourself busy and keep going.
Keep going, Sarah, you're nearly there.

idioms.def: to be enough for somebody until they get what they are waiting for
examples: Have an apple to keep you going till dinner time.

meanings.def: food, clothes and all the other things that a person needs to live; the cost of these things
examples: It's about time you got a job to earn your keep.

meanings.def: a large strong tower, built as part of an old castle
examples: He made his way up a flight of steep stairs and into the main keep of the castle.

meanings.def: to do useful or helpful things in return for being allowed to live or stay somewhere
examples: He was willing to earn his keep.

meanings.def: to be worth the amount of time or money that is being spent
examples: He felt he no longer deserved such a high salary. He just wasn't earning his keep.
All this new technology will have to earn its keep.

meanings.def: forever
examples: Is it yours for keeps or does he want it back?

idioms.def: to do useful or helpful things in return for being allowed to live or stay somewhere
examples: He was willing to earn his keep.
He felt he no longer deserved such a high salary. He just wasn't earning his keep.
All this new technology will have to earn its keep.
Is it yours for keeps or does he want it back?
